So these three key principles are as follows.
The best trades often fly in the face of the most recent market activity.
So what do we mean by that?
Do you remember what I said to you in earlier slides how if something's very obvious, if
there's a lot of information that is obviously available to the market.
then sometimes the best thing to do is actually what everyone else isn't doing.
So that's what we're trying to say and that's why V-reversals work so well because everyone
is caught still trying to sort of go with the prevailing trend and what they're actually
sort of forgetting is that we've got a very strong objective clue in the market
that that trend has now come to an end.
So sometimes the best trades to do are the ones that go against the most recent
market activity.
Now, I'm not saying you should be trading every kind of move.
What I am saying is when there's enough objectivity in the market, enough early clues, that is
when you want to go against the most recent market activity.
Our second key principle, never lose sight of the big picture.
Never lose sight of what the underlying trend is.
Are we bracketing?
Are we trending?
And then lastly, the more confirmation in the market, in other words, the more confirmation
you wait for or the more confirmation the market is giving you, the reduced probability
of success or the reduced probability of positive outcomes.
